title: Remove LaunchActivity
message:
Remove LaunchActivity

No need for a separate Activity here. Removing this should slightly improve
start-up time.

title: Introduce LaunchActivity splash screen
message:
Introduce LaunchActivity splash screen

There is a somewhat inevitable delay on launch while we start the service and
acquire the Camera device. This shows a fullscreen message letting the user
know the app is initializing, rather than not showing anything until the
initialization is complete (which looks like lag).

This approach has its flaws. For example, we use a theme to display the
background drawable for LaunchActivity rather than a real UI. This contains a
Bitmap for the loading graphic/text, so the text is hard-coded and cannot be
localized.

We could make the time-consuming tasks asynchronous and get the user to the
main UI almost immediately, but we don't really want them there until the
initialization is complete and we're ready to handle user input anyway.

title: Rewrite service-activity communication mechanisms
message:
Rewrite service-activity communication mechanisms

Services take a long time to shut down. There was an obscure case where leaving
the app and re-entering quickly could catch TorchService on its way down and
you'd wind up in an inconsistent state. To combat this (to a degree), I split
the service out into its own process and forcefully kill it when the app is
on its way out, rather than waiting for the very slow service lifecycle to
complete.

Because the service is now in another process, communication between the
service and MainActivity via LocalBroadcastManager is no longer an option.
Instead, I introduce a system BroadcastReceiver that the service can send
"command" intents to, which then just forwards them on to the activity using
the old LocalBroadcastManager. The activity continues to use startService() to
communicate to the service.

This rewrite should also fix the "auto on" and persistence features that were
partially broken coming in.

App module: don't abort on lint errors/warnings

This helps support newer Gradle and Android plugin versions while maintaining
expected build behavior. Without this, lint will abort the task if it finds any
errors/warnings and effectively break the build.

title: build.gradle: Fix Android Studio code inspection warnings
message:
build.gradle: Fix Android Studio code inspection warnings

Line 18/19: "Method call is ambiguous"
Line 21: "Cannot infer argument types"

These appear to be harmless, as the build still succeeds, but they were bothering me. Apparently,
Android Studio doesn't approve of assigning a blank signingConfig inside the buildType. Assigning it
inside the if-statement (after finding the storeFile environment variable and building the
signingConfig) makes it happy.

title: Change package name to all lowercase
message:
Change package name to all lowercase

Per the Java naming conventions for packages, the name should be all lowercase.

"Package names are written in all lower case to avoid conflict with the names of
classes or interfaces."

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/package/namingpkgs.html

title: Settings: use dedicated keys for SharedPreferences
message:
Settings: use dedicated keys for SharedPreferences

I was attempting to use one string resource for both the string that is seen
by the user as well as the key value for the SharedPreferences setting. But I
realized that when translated, if a user were to switch languages, they would
lose their settings because it would be looking for a key under the new,
translated name. Trying to utilize these strings for dual purposes is nonsense.

title: Settings: support dialog themes for Android API levels 11 and 14 explicitly
message:
Settings: support dialog themes for Android API levels 11 and 14 explicitly

Older versions of Android do not support fancy dialogs, so reduce the default
theme to just use plain Dialog. For Android 3.0, use Holo. For Android 4.0+, use
DeviceDefault.

title: Track user settings in main activity and pass them to the service on start
message:
Track user settings in main activity and pass them to the service on start

On a possibly unrelated note, I thought I witnessed a race condition involving
AsyncTask while testing this build, but I was unable to reproduce it and it
occurred while messing around with tweaks pretty heavily. May be ignorable, but
I'm including this warning in case I run into it later and need to circle back.

title: Listen for preference changes and notify the service if applicable
message:
Listen for preference changes and notify the service if applicable

This seems to work but it feels like it needs a refactor. We tell the service
about the persistence setting both when the user enables/disables it, as well as
when we toggle the torch. Should be no reason to send that information in both
places. Specifically, we should be able to remove it from the toggle intent, as
the service should already know about it. This would require notifying the
service of the settings near the beginning of the activity lifecycle (onStart?)
since the setting could be enabled on launch and we haven't seen a preference
change event yet.

title: Settings: change from Activity to Dialog via theme
message: Settings: change from Activity to Dialog via theme

title: Service: revert wrapping acquireCamera in AsyncTask
message:
Service: revert wrapping acquireCamera in AsyncTask

I believe this was causing a race condition (rarely, but enough that I noticed).
If the Auto On setting was enabled, occasionally the camera would be null when
CameraDevice attempted to toggle. It was hard to reproduce, but I saw it the
most when coming out of the Settings activity. I haven't seen it since applying
this change.

title: Service: wrap some of the longer running camera tasks in AsyncTask
message:
Service: wrap some of the longer running camera tasks in AsyncTask

Choreographer was indicating there was too much work being done in the main
thread, causing frame skipping. The two tasks in the service that were taking
the longest were acquiring the camera and starting the preview. This wraps both
in their own AsyncTask threads and eliminates the lag reported in logcat. Feels
like a bit of overkill, though - may not need to do this for acquiring the
camera.

title: Rename internal persistence setting references for consistency
message: Rename internal persistence setting references for consistency

title: Rename package to replace deprecated domain
message: Rename package to replace deprecated domain

title: Refactor service start timing and behavior to reduce toggle lag
message:
Refactor service start timing and behavior to reduce toggle lag

Start the service with the main activity so it can acquire the camera and start
the preview while everything is loading so the user can click the toggle and not
have to wait (as long) for the torch to come on. It has an unfortunate side
effect of reintroducing the startup lag that was fixed previously by removing
the pointless use of a fragment, because now it seems to be waiting for the
service or whatever the service is doing. May need to start it in another
process (probably bad)? Or completely abandon this approach and just have the
service load on boot and use a BroadcastReceiver to communicate with it? Lastly,
I believe the implementation in this commit is abusing startService calls, which
might also be remedied by switching to a BroadcastReceiver or something of that
nature.

title: Service: remove extraneous SurfaceHolder atomic locking code
message: Service: remove extraneous SurfaceHolder atomic locking code

title: Remove MainFragment and collapse content into parent MainActivity
message:
Remove MainFragment and collapse content into parent MainActivity

A Fragment adds no value to this particular app as it really only has one view
(plus the PreferenceActivity).

Note: git detected renames on the layout files because the content was moved
from fragment_main to activity_main so the similarity index was extremely high.
In actual fact, the fragment layout files were deleted and the activity layout
files were updated.

title: Refactor overlay layout and perform general layout cleanup
message:
Refactor overlay layout and perform general layout cleanup

Changing the overlay to a FrameLayout and putting a black View on top of the
SurfaceView hides it from the user (again).

Also, reformatted all XML files using Android Studio's reformat functionality.
It will probably decide to redo them in the future. :P

title: Merge branch 'service'
message:
Merge branch 'service'

This introduces the Persistence feature which enables the torch to remain lit
after leaving the app. The implementation uses a Service.

title: Service: move stopService call in main activity from onDestroy to onStop
message:
Service: move stopService call in main activity from onDestroy to onStop

This creates the annoying side effect of disabling the torch when you open the
Settings preference activity because the main activity's onStop is called. But
onDestroy doesn't get called if you leave the app by means other than the Back
button (using Home, Recents, etc.) so the torch will stay lit regardless of the
current persistence setting state. There should be a way to get the best of both
worlds, but for now I'm choosing the lesser of two evils.

title: Service: enter foreground mode if persistence is enabled
message:
Service: enter foreground mode if persistence is enabled

Create a notification that will be present when the service has entered
foreground mode (theoretically, preventing the system from garbage collecting
it). This will occur if the user has enabled the persistence setting. Otherwise,
no notification will be created and the service will not be put in foreground
mode.

Also in this commit, change the service member isRunning to a private member and
implement getter method isRunning() instead. Not sure why it wasn't done this
way to begin with, must've been tired.

title: Service: toggle the torch once the overlay surface holder is available
message: Service: toggle the torch once the overlay surface holder is available

title: Service: publicly track own state (isRunning) and honor persistence setting
message:
Service: publicly track own state (isRunning) and honor persistence setting

MainFragment will use the public isReady boolean of mTorchService to determine
the current state of the torch (enabled/disabled) and set the image button
accordingly. Also, MainFragment will stop the service in onDestroy() if the
persistence setting is disabled (else, do nothing and let the service run).

title: Service: start/stop on click and update image button accordingly
message: Service: start/stop on click and update image button accordingly

Service: attempt to make a Bound service

Try to start/stop by binding/unbinding. Toggle (ImageButton) appears to start
service on bind and stop service on unbind, but it's flaky. Also, rename
"hidden" stuff to "overlay" (calling it what it is). It's not actually hidden,
anyway. You can see the 1x1 preview in the bottom center of the display,
currently. May want to fix by wrapping in another layout.

title: Service: completely break app while transitioning things to service
message:
Service: completely break app while transitioning things to service

Comment out normal app functionality. Create "hidden" SurfaceView (camera
preview) overlay and callbacks in the service. Meanwhile, chaos all around.

title: Service: lay groundwork for a service to handle camera operations
message:
Service: lay groundwork for a service to handle camera operations

The service loads on boot if the app has been opened at least once. If not, the
app will start the service on first launch. The service does a check for the
camera flash feature and stops itself if the feature is not available.

Android Studio also decided the XML formatting in the manifest needed to be
tweaked during this commit. It will probably be different next time. :P
